column1: Below are twelve alphabetical lists of cities in the Netherlands ordered by province.
== Distinctions ==
There are no formal rules in the Netherlands to distinguish cities from other settlements. Smaller settlements are usually called dorp
column2: comparable with villages in English speaking countries. The Dutch word for city is stad (plural: steden). The intermediate category of town does not exist in the Netherlands.

column1: Historically
column2: there existed systems of city rights
column4: which defined the status of a place: a stad or dorp. Cities were self-governing and had several privileges. In 1851 the granting of city rights and all privileges and special status of cities were abolished. Since then
column5: the only local administrative unit is the municipality. Regardless of this legal change
column6: many people still use the old city rights as a criterion: certain small settlements proudly call themselves a stad because they historically had city rights
column8: newer towns may not get this recognition.

column1: Geographers and policy makers can distinguish between places with respect to the number of inhabitants or the economic and planological functions within a larger area. Hence
column2: settlements can be considered a city if they function as an urban center in a rural area; while larger population centres in densely populated areas are often neither considered a village nor a city and are usually referred to with the generic word plaats (place). Inhabitants may also base their choice of words just on the subjective way they experience life at a certain place.

column1: When discussing cities
column2: the distinction is sometimes made between the cities in two urban network.

column1: The largest urban network is known as "Randstad"
column2: including the largest 4 cities in the Netherlands (Amsterdam

column1: The 2nd urban network in the Netherlands is known as 'Brabantstad'
A partnership of the Brabant "Big 5" "Eindhoven
In addition
